definition: A password set to restrict access to BIOS or system settings, usually for security purposes.
Firmware that initializes and tests hardware during the booting process and provides runtime services for the operating system.
Settings in BIOS/UEFI that determine the order and devices the computer will attempt to boot from.
A password required at startup to allow the system to boot, preventing unauthorized access.
A small amount of memory on a motherboard that stores BIOS settings and is powered by a battery.
A battery that provides power to the CMOS memory to retain BIOS settings when the system is powered off.
A Windows tool used to view and manage hardware devices and their drivers.
A security feature in BIOS that prevents certain types of malware from executing in memory.
A BIOS feature that enables encryption of a storage drive to protect data from unauthorized access.
An adapter bracket that provides external SATA ports for connecting eSATA devices.
A PCI or PCIe expansion card that adds eSATA ports to a computer for connecting external SATA drives.
BIOS data that stores information about system resources like IRQs, DMA channels, and I/O addresses.
BIOS or UEFI settings that allow adjustment of system or CPU fan speeds for cooling and noise management.
A process that upgrades the system's BIOS or firmware to fix bugs, add features, or improve security.
The process of writing a new BIOS version to the motherboard's flash memory.
A TPM implementation in firmware that provides hardware-based security functions without a separate TPM chip.
A unique identifier used by the CPU to communicate with hardware devices.
An error often caused by a failing CMOS battery or misconfigured BIOS settings.
A BIOS feature that alerts users if the case has been opened or hardware tampered with.
A hardware signal that allows devices to interrupt the CPU to request processing time.
A small connector on a motherboard or device used to configure hardware settings by connecting pins.
A BIOS-enabled anti-theft feature that helps locate a stolen computer.
A unique location in memory used to store or retrieve data by the CPU or devices.
Passwords set within the BIOS to restrict access to settings or to the system at boot.
A Windows database that stores configuration settings and options for the operating system and applications.
A UEFI feature that ensures only trusted software and operating systems can boot on the device.
BIOS or UEFI options that control authentication, encryption, and other security features.
The BIOS/UEFI interface used to configure system settings, hardware, and security options.

term: system attempts to boot to an  device
definition: Occurs when the BIOS/UEFI tries to boot from a specific device, such as a hard drive or USB drive, based on boot order settings.
Hardware resources such as memory addresses, IRQs, and DMA channels allocated to devices for proper functioning.
Modern firmware interface that replaces BIOS, supporting larger drives, faster booting, and secure boot features.
A card added to a system to provide additional USB ports.
Settings that control access to USB devices, often used for security and data protection.
